word: Actions speak louder than words
definition: What you do is more important than what you say. People judge you by your behavior, not your promises.
example: He always promises to help but never does. Actions speak louder than words.

word: Better late than never
definition: It is better to arrive or do something late than not at all.
example: You finally called me back after two weeks? Well, better late than never!

word: No pain, no gain
definition: You have to work hard and sometimes suffer to achieve your goals.
example: My muscles hurt from exercising, but no pain, no gain!

word: Practice makes perfect
definition: The more you practice something, the better you become at it.
example: Don't give up on learning guitar. Practice makes perfect.

word: Honesty is the best policy
definition: It is always better to tell the truth than to lie.
example: I admitted my mistake to my boss. Honesty is the best policy.

word: The early bird catches the worm
definition: People who start early or arrive first have a better chance of success.
example: I got to the sale first and found great deals. The early bird catches the worm!

word: An apple a day keeps the doctor away
definition: Eating healthy food regularly helps you stay healthy and avoid illness.
example: I eat fresh vegetables every day. An apple a day keeps the doctor away.

word: Easy come, easy go
definition: Something gained easily is also lost easily, especially money.
example: He won $1000 gambling but lost it all the next day. Easy come, easy go.

word: Time is money
definition: Time is valuable and should not be wasted because it can be used to earn money.
example: Stop chatting and get back to work. Time is money!

word: Love is blind
definition: When you love someone, you cannot see their faults or mistakes.
example: She doesn't see any of his bad habits. Love is blind.

word: Don't count your chickens before they hatch
definition: Don't assume you will be successful before it actually happens. Don't celebrate too early.
example: You haven't passed the exam yet, so don't count your chickens before they hatch.

word: Every cloud has a silver lining
definition: Every difficult or sad situation has a positive or hopeful side.
example: Losing my job led me to start my own business. Every cloud has a silver lining.

word: Rome wasn't built in a day
definition: Important achievements take time and patience. Don't expect instant results.
example: You can't become fluent in English in one month. Rome wasn't built in a day.

word: When in Rome, do as the Romans do
definition: When visiting a foreign place, follow the local customs and behave like the local people.
example: In Japan, I took off my shoes indoors. When in Rome, do as the Romans do.

word: You can't judge a book by its cover
definition: You cannot know what someone or something is really like just by looking at their appearance.
example: That old car runs perfectly! You can't judge a book by its cover.

word: Two wrongs don't make a right
definition: If someone does something bad to you, doing something bad back to them is not justified.
example: He insulted you, but insulting him back won't help. Two wrongs don't make a right.

word: A penny saved is a penny earned
definition: Money that you save is just as valuable as money you work hard to earn.
example: I pack my lunch instead of eating out. A penny saved is a penny earned.

word: Look before you leap
definition: Think carefully about the possible problems before making a decision or taking action.
example: Before investing all your savings, look before you leap.

word: A friend in need is a friend indeed
definition: A real friend is someone who helps you when you are in trouble, not just in good times.
example: She stayed with me when I was sick. A friend in need is a friend indeed.

word: Birds of a feather flock together
definition: People who have similar interests, ideas, or characteristics tend to spend time together.
example: All the artists in town hang out together. Birds of a feather flock together.

word: Beggars can't be choosers
definition: When you need something badly, you must accept whatever is offered without being picky.
example: The free apartment is small, but beggars can't be choosers.

word: Don't put all your eggs in one basket
definition: Don't risk everything on a single opportunity. Spread your resources or investments.
example: Invest in different stocks. Don't put all your eggs in one basket.

word: The grass is always greener on the other side
definition: Other people's situations always seem better than your own, but they often aren't.
example: He thinks my job is easy, but the grass is always greener on the other side.

word: Where there's smoke, there's fire
definition: If there are rumors or signs of something, there is probably some truth behind them.
example: Everyone says he's dishonest. Where there's smoke, there's fire.

word: You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make it drink
definition: You can give someone an opportunity, but you cannot force them to take it.
example: I showed him how to study, but he won't do it. You can lead a horse to water, but you can't make it drink.

word: When the cat's away, the mice will play
definition: When a person in authority is absent, people will behave badly or lazily.
example: The workers stopped working when the boss left. When the cat's away, the mice will play.

word: Kill two birds with one stone
definition: Accomplish two different tasks with a single action.
example: By cycling to work, I exercise and save money. I kill two birds with one stone.

word: Don't bite the hand that feeds you
definition: Don't be ungrateful to or harm someone who helps or supports you.
example: Don't complain about your boss publicly. Don't bite the hand that feeds you.

word: A picture is worth a thousand words
definition: An image can convey a complex idea more effectively than a long explanation.
example: Instead of describing the accident, just show the photo. A picture is worth a thousand words.

word: Blood is thicker than water
definition: Family relationships are stronger and more important than relationships with friends or others.
example: I have to help my brother first. Blood is thicker than water.

word: The pen is mightier than the sword
definition: Writing, ideas, and communication are more powerful and effective than violence or military force.
example: The journalist's article changed the law. The pen is mightier than the sword.

word: All that glitters is not gold
definition: Things that appear attractive or valuable on the surface may not be so in reality.
example: That fancy car broke down after a week. All that glitters is not gold.

word: A leopard can't change its spots
definition: People cannot change their fundamental nature or character, especially bad habits.
example: He promised to be honest, but he lied again. A leopard can't change its spots.

word: The squeaky wheel gets the grease
definition: The person who complains the most or makes the most noise gets attention and help first.
example: I kept asking for a raise until I got one. The squeaky wheel gets the grease.

word: Curiosity killed the cat
definition: Being too curious or nosy about things can lead to trouble or danger.
example: Stop asking about his private life. Curiosity killed the cat.

word: The road to hell is paved with good intentions
definition: Good intentions alone are not enough; what matters is actually doing good things, not just planning to.
example: He meant to help but made things worse. The road to hell is paved with good intentions.

word: You reap what you sow
definition: Your actions have consequences. You will eventually experience the results of your behavior.
example: He never studied and failed the exam. You reap what you sow.

word: Fortune favors the bold
definition: People who take risks and are brave are more likely to be successful.
example: I asked for a promotion and got it! Fortune favors the bold.

word: Absence makes the heart grow fonder
definition: When you are away from someone you love, your love for them becomes stronger.
example: After a month apart, we missed each other so much. Absence makes the heart grow fonder.

word: Too many cooks spoil the broth
definition: When too many people try to do the same job, the result is often bad.
example: With five managers giving different instructions, the project failed. Too many cooks spoil the broth.

word: People who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones
definition: Don't criticize others for faults that you have yourself.
example: You're always late too, so don't criticize me. People who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones.

word: A rolling stone gathers no moss
definition: A person who keeps moving from place to place or changing jobs will not accumulate wealth or responsibilities.
example: He changes jobs every year and has no savings. A rolling stone gathers no moss.

word: The apple doesn't fall far from the tree
definition: Children often behave like their parents and inherit their characteristics.
example: She became a doctor like her mother. The apple doesn't fall far from the tree.

word: Don't cry over spilled milk
definition: Don't waste time being upset about something that has already happened and cannot be changed.
example: You lost the game. Don't cry over spilled milk; just practice for next time.

word: Necessity is the mother of invention
definition: When people really need something, they find creative ways to get or create it.
example: Without money for tools, he built his own. Necessity is the mother of invention.

word: Great minds think alike
definition: Intelligent people often have the same ideas or opinions (often used humorously).
example: We both chose the same restaurant! Great minds think alike.

word: Beauty is in the eye of the beholder
definition: What one person finds beautiful, another may not. Beauty is subjective.
example: I love that painting, but my friend hates it. Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

word: Strike while the iron is hot
definition: Take advantage of an opportunity immediately, while conditions are favorable.
example: The boss is in a good mood. Ask for a raise now! Strike while the iron is hot.

word: One man's trash is another man's treasure
definition: What one person considers worthless may be valuable to someone else.
example: I sold my old records online for good money. One man's trash is another man's treasure.

word: The best things in life are free
definition: The most valuable things, like love, friendship, and health, don't cost money.
example: Spending time with family makes me happiest. The best things in life are free.

word: Haste makes waste
definition: Doing things too quickly often leads to mistakes and wasted effort.
example: Slow down and check your work. Haste makes waste.

word: Out of sight, out of mind
definition: When you don't see someone or something, you tend to forget about them.
example: After she moved away, we lost touch. Out of sight, out of mind.

word: What goes around comes around
definition: The way you treat others will eventually come back to you, good or bad.
example: He was always helpful, and now everyone helps him. What goes around comes around.

word: Money doesn't grow on trees
definition: Money is not easily obtained and should not be wasted.
example: You can't buy everything you want. Money doesn't grow on trees.

word: The bigger they are, the harder they fall
definition: Powerful or important people suffer more when they fail.
example: The CEO lost everything in the scandal. The bigger they are, the harder they fall.

word: Don't make a mountain out of a molehill
definition: Don't treat a small problem as if it were a big, serious issue.
example: It's just a small scratch on the car. Don't make a mountain out of a molehill.

word: Two heads are better than one
definition: Working with someone else can help you solve problems more effectively.
example: Let's work on this together. Two heads are better than one.

word: If the shoe fits, wear it
definition: If a criticism or description applies to you, accept it.
example: I said lazy people fail. If the shoe fits, wear it.

word: Let sleeping dogs lie
definition: Don't disturb a situation that might cause problems if you interfere.
example: Don't mention the old argument. Let sleeping dogs lie.

word: Never put off till tomorrow what you can do today
definition: Don't delay doing something that can be done now.
example: Finish your homework now. Never put off till tomorrow what you can do today.

word: A watched pot never boils
definition: Time seems to pass slowly when you're waiting anxiously for something.
example: Stop checking your email every minute. A watched pot never boils.

word: Laughter is the best medicine
definition: Being happy and laughing helps you feel better when you're sad or sick.
example: Watch a funny movie when you're stressed. Laughter is the best medicine.

word: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step
definition: Even the biggest task starts with one small action.
example: Just start writing one page. A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.

word: Ignorance is bliss
definition: Sometimes it's better not to know about problems because knowing causes worry.
example: I was happier before I knew about the company's troubles. Ignorance is bliss.

word: Old habits die hard
definition: It's difficult to change behavior or habits you've had for a long time.
example: He still smokes even after the doctor's warning. Old habits die hard.

word: Silence is golden
definition: Sometimes it's better to say nothing than to speak.
example: Don't argue with angry customers. Silence is golden.

word: All good things must come to an end
definition: Nothing pleasant lasts forever.
example: Our vacation is over. All good things must come to an end.

word: There's no place like home
definition: Home is the most comfortable and satisfying place to be.
example: After a long trip, I'm glad to be back. There's no place like home.

word: It takes two to tango
definition: Both people involved in a situation are responsible for it.
example: They both caused the argument. It takes two to tango.

word: If it ain't broke, don't fix it
definition: Don't change something that is working well.
example: The old system works fine. If it ain't broke, don't fix it.

word: The pot calling the kettle black
definition: Criticizing someone for a fault you have yourself.
example: You're calling me lazy? That's the pot calling the kettle black!

word: Every dog has its day
definition: Everyone will have success or good luck at some point in their life.
example: I finally won the competition! Every dog has its day.

word: Don't look a gift horse in the mouth
definition: Don't criticize or be ungrateful for something given to you for free.
example: The free laptop is old, but don't look a gift horse in the mouth.

word: Jack of all trades, master of none
definition: Someone who can do many things but is not an expert in any of them.
example: He can fix anything but not perfectly. He's a jack of all trades, master of none.

word: Barking dogs seldom bite
definition: People who threaten loudly rarely take action.
example: He threatens to sue but never does. Barking dogs seldom bite.

word: An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure
definition: It's easier to prevent problems than to fix them later.
example: Regular car maintenance saves expensive repairs. An ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

word: Familiarity breeds contempt
definition: Knowing someone or something too well can make you lose respect for them.
example: Living together, they started to annoy each other. Familiarity breeds contempt.

word: Nothing ventured, nothing gained
definition: You must take risks to achieve something worthwhile.
example: I'll apply for that dream job. Nothing ventured, nothing gained.

word: The truth will out
definition: The truth will eventually be discovered, no matter how hard people try to hide it.
example: They tried to cover up the scandal, but the truth will out.

word: Still waters run deep
definition: A quiet person often has deep thoughts or hidden talents.
example: She's quiet but incredibly smart. Still waters run deep.

word: Empty vessels make the most noise
definition: Foolish or ignorant people often talk the most.
example: He speaks loudly but knows nothing. Empty vessels make the most noise.

word: One swallow does not make a summer
definition: A single event doesn't mean a trend has started.
example: He won one game, but one swallow does not make a summer.

word: There are plenty of fish in the sea
definition: There are many other opportunities or people available, especially after a breakup.
example: Don't be sad about the breakup. There are plenty of fish in the sea.

word: You can't have your cake and eat it too
definition: You can't have two incompatible things at the same time.
example: You want to save money but buy expensive things? You can't have your cake and eat it too.

word: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
definition: Something you already have is more valuable than something you might get.
example: Take this job offer now. A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

word: Make hay while the sun shines
definition: Take advantage of good conditions while they last.
example: Business is booming, so work hard now. Make hay while the sun shines.

word: A chain is only as strong as its weakest link
definition: A group or organization is only as good as its weakest member.
example: Train all employees well. A chain is only as strong as its weakest link.

word: There's no such thing as a free lunch
definition: Everything has a cost, even if it's not obvious.
example: That free trial requires your credit card. There's no such thing as a free lunch.

word: Fools rush in where angels fear to tread
definition: Inexperienced people often act carelessly in dangerous situations that wiser people avoid.
example: He invested without research. Fools rush in where angels fear to tread.

word: The devil is in the details
definition: Small details in a plan or document can cause problems if not carefully examined.
example: Read the contract carefully. The devil is in the details.

word: Pride comes before a fall
definition: If you are too proud or confident, you will make mistakes that lead to failure.
example: He bragged about winning, then lost the final. Pride comes before a fall.

word: Half a loaf is better than none
definition: Getting only part of what you want is better than getting nothing at all.
example: I only got a partial refund, but half a loaf is better than none.

word: Don't throw the baby out with the bathwater
definition: Don't discard something valuable while trying to get rid of something unwanted.
example: The plan has problems, but don't throw the baby out with the bathwater.

word: He who hesitates is lost
definition: If you delay making a decision, you may lose the opportunity.
example: I waited too long, and someone else got the apartment. He who hesitates is lost.

word: Let bygones be bygones
definition: Forget past disagreements and move forward.
example: Let's stop fighting about old problems. Let bygones be bygones.

word: A stitch in time saves nine
definition: Fixing a small problem now prevents it from becoming a bigger problem later.
example: Fix that small leak now. A stitch in time saves nine.

word: Give credit where credit is due
definition: Acknowledge and praise people who deserve it.
example: She did most of the work, so give credit where credit is due.

word: Discretion is the better part of valor
definition: Sometimes it's braver to avoid danger than to face it unnecessarily.
example: I didn't argue with the angry man. Discretion is the better part of valor.

word: Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it
definition: If you don't learn from history, you will make the same mistakes again.
example: Study what caused past failures. Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.

word: Don't burn your bridges
definition: Don't damage relationships or ruin opportunities that you might need later.
example: Leave your job politely. Don't burn your bridges.

word: Better safe than sorry
definition: It's better to be careful and avoid risks than to regret later.
example: Wear your seatbelt. Better safe than sorry.

word: Cleanliness is next to godliness
definition: Being clean is almost as important as being morally good.
example: Always keep your room tidy. Cleanliness is next to godliness.

word: First come, first served
definition: People who arrive first get served or helped before others.
example: Get there early for the best seats. First come, first served.

word: Good things come to those who wait
definition: Patience is rewarded; if you wait, you will get what you want.
example: Be patient with your career. Good things come to those who wait.

word: It's never too late to learn
definition: You can learn new things at any age.
example: My grandmother started painting at 70. It's never too late to learn.

word: Knowledge is power
definition: The more you know, the more influence and capability you have.
example: Keep studying and reading. Knowledge is power.

word: Like father, like son
definition: Sons often resemble their fathers in behavior or appearance.
example: He loves cars just like his dad. Like father, like son.

word: Misery loves company
definition: Unhappy people like to be around other unhappy people.
example: He always complains to others. Misery loves company.

word: No news is good news
definition: If you haven't heard anything, assume everything is fine.
example: The doctor hasn't called back. No news is good news.

word: Once bitten, twice shy
definition: After a bad experience, you become more careful.
example: I won't invest in that company again. Once bitten, twice shy.

word: Out of the frying pan into the fire
definition: Going from a bad situation to an even worse one.
example: He quit his bad job and got a worse one. Out of the frying pan into the fire.

word: Patience is a virtue
definition: Being patient is a good and admirable quality.
example: Wait calmly for your turn. Patience is a virtue.

word: Prevention is better than cure
definition: It's better to stop problems before they happen than to fix them later.
example: Exercise regularly to stay healthy. Prevention is better than cure.

word: Seeing is believing
definition: You need to see something yourself to believe it's true.
example: I didn't believe the magic trick until I saw it. Seeing is believing.

word: Slow and steady wins the race
definition: Consistent, patient effort leads to success.
example: Don't rush your studies. Slow and steady wins the race.

word: The early bird gets the worm
definition: Those who act early have the best chance of success.
example: Apply for jobs now before others do. The early bird gets the worm.

word: There's no time like the present
definition: Now is the best time to do something; don't delay.
example: Start your project today. There's no time like the present.

word: Time heals all wounds
definition: Emotional pain will eventually go away with time.
example: You'll feel better about the breakup eventually. Time heals all wounds.

word: To each his own
definition: Everyone has their own preferences and tastes.
example: I don't like that music, but to each his own.

word: Truth is stranger than fiction
definition: Real life is sometimes more surprising than made-up stories.
example: He actually won the lottery twice! Truth is stranger than fiction.

word: United we stand, divided we fall
definition: People are stronger when they work together.
example: Let's cooperate as a team. United we stand, divided we fall.

word: Variety is the spice of life
definition: Having different experiences makes life interesting.
example: Try new foods when you travel. Variety is the spice of life.

word: Walls have ears
definition: Be careful what you say because someone might be listening.
example: Don't discuss secrets here. Walls have ears.

word: What doesn't kill you makes you stronger
definition: Difficult experiences help you become more resilient.
example: That failure taught me a lot. What doesn't kill you makes you stronger.

word: When it rains, it pours
definition: When something bad happens, more bad things often follow.
example: I lost my job and my car broke down. When it rains, it pours.

word: You can't make an omelet without breaking eggs
definition: You can't achieve something without some sacrifice or difficulty.
example: Some people will be upset by the changes, but you can't make an omelet without breaking eggs.

word: You can't teach an old dog new tricks
definition: It's difficult to change someone's habits, especially older people.
example: My grandfather refuses to use a smartphone. You can't teach an old dog new tricks.

word: Your guess is as good as mine
definition: I don't know the answer either.
example: Where did he go? Your guess is as good as mine.

word: A bad workman blames his tools
definition: Someone who does poor work blames their equipment instead of themselves.
example: He said the computer was too slow. A bad workman blames his tools.

word: A fool and his money are soon parted
definition: Foolish people spend or lose their money quickly.
example: He bought a useless gadget. A fool and his money are soon parted.

word: A little knowledge is a dangerous thing
definition: Knowing only a little about something can lead to overconfidence and mistakes.
example: He thinks he can fix the car after watching one video. A little knowledge is a dangerous thing.

word: A man is known by the company he keeps
definition: People judge you by the friends you have.
example: Choose your friends wisely. A man is known by the company he keeps.

word: A problem shared is a problem halved
definition: Talking about your problems with someone makes them easier to deal with.
example: Tell me what's wrong. A problem shared is a problem halved.

word: A word to the wise is enough
definition: Smart people understand with just a small hint.
example: I'll just say be careful around him. A word to the wise is enough.

word: All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy
definition: Working all the time without rest or fun is unhealthy.
example: Take a vacation! All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy.

word: An eye for an eye
definition: If someone hurts you, you should punish them equally.
example: He broke my toy, so I broke his. An eye for an eye.

word: Ask no questions and hear no lies
definition: If you don't ask about something, you won't be told lies about it.
example: I didn't ask where he got the money. Ask no questions and hear no lies.

word: Bad news travels fast
definition: People spread negative information quickly.
example: Everyone heard about his mistake immediately. Bad news travels fast.

word: Charity begins at home
definition: Take care of your family and close ones before helping others.
example: Help your parents first. Charity begins at home.

word: Cut your coat according to your cloth
definition: Live within your means; don't spend more than you have.
example: Buy a cheaper car. Cut your coat according to your cloth.

word: Distance makes the heart grow fonder
definition: Being apart from someone makes you love them more.
example: After studying abroad, I missed my family so much. Distance makes the heart grow fonder.

word: Don't cross the bridge until you come to it
definition: Don't worry about problems until they actually happen.
example: Stop worrying about the exam. Don't cross the bridge until you come to it.

word: Don't judge a man until you've walked in his shoes
definition: Don't criticize someone until you understand their situation.
example: You don't know what she's been through. Don't judge until you've walked in her shoes.

word: Even a broken clock is right twice a day
definition: Even someone who is usually wrong can be correct sometimes.
example: He finally gave good advice. Even a broken clock is right twice a day.

word: Experience is the best teacher
definition: You learn best by actually doing things yourself.
example: I learned more from my mistakes than from books. Experience is the best teacher.

word: Failing to plan is planning to fail
definition: Without proper planning, you are likely to fail.
example: Make a study schedule. Failing to plan is planning to fail.

word: Give a man a fish and feed him for a day; teach him to fish and feed him for life
definition: It's better to teach someone a skill than to do things for them.
example: Show him how to solve the problem himself. Teach a man to fish.

word: God helps those who help themselves
definition: You must make an effort; you can't just wait for luck.

word: He who laughs last laughs longest
definition: The final winner has the greatest satisfaction.
example: They mocked me, but I won in the end. He who laughs last laughs longest.

word: Home is where the heart is
definition: Your true home is where the people you love are.
example: I feel at home wherever my family is. Home is where the heart is.

word: If at first you don't succeed, try, try again
definition: Keep trying until you succeed, even after failures.
example: Failed the test? Study harder and try again. If at first you don't succeed, try again.

word: If you want something done right, do it yourself
definition: You can only be sure of quality when you do it yourself.

word: It takes a thief to catch a thief
definition: The best person to catch a wrongdoer is someone who knows their tricks.

word: Keep your friends close and your enemies closer
definition: Watch your enemies carefully to know what they're planning.
example: I stay friendly with my rival to know his plans. Keep your enemies closer.

word: Least said, soonest mended
definition: The less you say about a problem, the faster it will be forgotten.
example: Don't keep talking about the argument. Least said, soonest mended.

word: Let the buyer beware
definition: It's the buyer's responsibility to check quality before purchasing.
example: Check the used car carefully. Let the buyer beware.

word: Lightning never strikes twice
definition: The same unlikely event won't happen again to the same person.
example: He won't have another accident there. Lightning never strikes twice.

word: Live and learn
definition: You learn from your experiences, especially mistakes.
example: I trusted the wrong person. Live and learn.

word: Live and let live
definition: Accept others' differences and don't interfere with how they live.
example: His lifestyle is different, but live and let live.

word: Look on the bright side
definition: Try to see the positive aspects of a bad situation.
example: You didn't get the job, but look on the bright sideâ€”now you can find a better one.

word: Many hands make light work
definition: A task becomes easier when more people help.
example: Let's all clean together. Many hands make light work.

word: Mind your own business
definition: Don't interfere in other people's affairs.
example: Stop asking about my salary. Mind your own business.

word: Money talks
definition: Money gives people power and influence.
example: He got special treatment because he's rich. Money talks.

word: Necessity knows no law
definition: In desperate situations, people will do anything, even break rules.
example: He stole bread to feed his family. Necessity knows no law.

word: Never look a gift horse in the mouth
definition: Don't question the value of a gift; be grateful.
example: The free phone is old but works fine. Never look a gift horse in the mouth.

word: Never say never
definition: Anything is possible; don't rule out possibilities.
example: I thought I'd never travel abroad, but I did. Never say never.

word: No man is an island
definition: Nobody can live completely alone; we all need others.
example: Ask for help when you need it. No man is an island.

word: Nothing is certain but death and taxes
definition: Death and taxes are the only things guaranteed in life.
example: You can't avoid paying taxes. Nothing is certain but death and taxes.

word: One good turn deserves another
definition: If someone helps you, you should help them in return.
example: He helped me move, so I helped him paint. One good turn deserves another.

word: Opposites attract
definition: People with different personalities are often attracted to each other.
example: She's outgoing and he's shy, but they're perfect together. Opposites attract.

word: Penny wise, pound foolish
definition: Being careful with small amounts but wasteful with large ones.
example: He saves on coffee but buys expensive cars. Penny wise, pound foolish.

word: Practice what you preach
definition: Do what you tell others to do.
example: You tell me to exercise but you don't. Practice what you preach.

word: Revenge is a dish best served cold
definition: Revenge is more satisfying when it's planned and delayed.
example: He waited years to get back at his rival. Revenge is best served cold.

word: Rome was not built in a day
definition: Great achievements take time.
example: Don't expect instant results. Rome was not built in a day.

word: Save for a rainy day
definition: Save money for future emergencies.
example: Put some money aside each month. Save for a rainy day.

word: Seek and you shall find
definition: If you look hard enough, you will find what you need.
example: Keep searching for job opportunities. Seek and you shall find.

word: Spare the rod, spoil the child
definition: Children need discipline to develop properly.
example: Set rules for your kids. Spare the rod, spoil the child.

word: Speak of the devil
definition: Said when someone you were just talking about appears.
example: We were just discussing John, and here he comes. Speak of the devil!

word: Speech is silver, silence is golden
definition: Speaking is good, but sometimes staying quiet is better.
example: Don't say anything in this meeting. Speech is silver, silence is golden.

word: The best defense is a good offense
definition: Attacking is the best way to protect yourself.
example: In business, launch products before competitors. The best defense is a good offense.

word: The customer is always right
definition: Businesses should satisfy customers even if they're wrong.
example: Apologize to the customer. The customer is always right.

word: The end justifies the means
definition: If the result is good, the method used doesn't matter.
example: He lied to protect her. The end justifies the means.

word: The leopard cannot change his spots
definition: People cannot change their basic nature.
example: He promised to change but didn't. The leopard cannot change his spots.

word: The more things change, the more they stay the same
definition: Despite apparent changes, fundamental things remain unchanged.
example: New technology, same problems. The more things change, the more they stay the same.

word: The proof is in the pudding
definition: You can only judge something by its results.
example: Let's see if the plan works. The proof is in the pudding.

word: The show must go on
definition: Despite difficulties, you must continue.
example: Even though she was sick, she performed. The show must go on.

word: There are two sides to every story
definition: Every situation can be seen from different perspectives.
example: Hear his side too. There are two sides to every story.

word: There's a time and place for everything
definition: Some things are only appropriate in certain situations.
example: Don't joke at funerals. There's a time and place for everything.

word: There's more than one way to skin a cat
definition: There are many ways to achieve the same goal.
example: Try a different approach. There's more than one way to skin a cat.

word: There's no smoke without fire
definition: Rumors usually have some basis in truth.
example: People keep saying he cheats. There's no smoke without fire.

word: Think before you speak
definition: Consider the effect of your words before saying them.
example: Don't say something you'll regret. Think before you speak.

word: Those who live by the sword die by the sword
definition: People who use violence will eventually suffer from it.
example: The gangster was killed by his enemies. Those who live by the sword die by the sword.

word: Tomorrow is another day
definition: Things can improve in the future; don't lose hope.
example: Today was tough, but tomorrow is another day.

word: Treat others as you wish to be treated
definition: Be kind to others if you want them to be kind to you.
example: Be respectful to everyone. Treat others as you wish to be treated.

word: Turn over a new leaf
definition: Start behaving better; make a fresh start.
example: After prison, he turned over a new leaf.

word: Two can play at that game
definition: I can do the same thing you're doing to me.
example: You're ignoring me? Two can play at that game.

word: Waste not, want not
definition: If you don't waste things, you'll always have enough.
example: Finish all your food. Waste not, want not.

word: Well begun is half done
definition: A good start makes the rest of the work easier.
example: Plan your project carefully at the start. Well begun is half done.

word: What you see is what you get
definition: This person or thing is exactly as they appear.
example: I'm honest and direct. What you see is what you get.

word: Where there's a will, there's a way
definition: If you really want to do something, you'll find a way.
example: You can finish college if you try. Where there's a will, there's a way.
